turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Hi, hello. I'm Doctor Jacob and welcome to Babylon. Hello. Hi. So just before we start, is it alright if you could confirm your name for me please?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNIN/> Hi there.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNSURE>get to</UNSURE> my name <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>. And your date of birth?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Fourteenth November nineteen ninety six.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And your address for me please?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: And twenty eight Great Road SW nineteen one EZ.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: That's correct. And just to confirm that you're in a secure location, and we can have a confidential conversation.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. So you've mentioned in <UNIN/> in our notes that you've got some tightness. If you'd like to tell me a bit more about it please.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah <UNIN/> about two to three days ago, I was running with a friend. And usually I can talk to her whilst I run, but I found myself actually short of breath. I'm <UNSURE>not really sure of that</UNSURE> when I'm walking. Um, but definitely um, if I'm walking briskly now. Um, and I've used my blue inhaler but to no avail. It hasn't really helped me.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNIN/>. <UNSURE>OK</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, ohh yeah, so I'm having, I'm just wheezing a bit, and coughing and just generally a bit short of breath

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Wheezing and coughing, OK. And you've mentioned you're using the blue inhaler. So, how often are you using the blue inhaler?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, I think I'm just using that as and when I have symptoms.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah. So, um, at the moment you are having shortness of breath. So, are you using it every day at the moment?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, yeah, and morning or evening to kinda prevent it as well.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, and um what, which colour? What's the name of your preventor?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, it's blue. Um, I think, in totality, I'm <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> Salbutamol, Flanel <UNSURE>Bactroban</UNSURE> and Hydrocortisone that I'm taking as well.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. So could you repeat that? <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Er, Cetraben and Hydrocortisone.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And hydrocortisone. So you'd have eczema also, yeah?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: What's that, sorry?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: You do have a history of eczema, <UNIN/>?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Em, my brother is asthmatic and my sister has eczema. Em, and I've got a few issues, um, that I think could be <UNSURE>eczema</UNSURE> as well.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, right. So coming back to your, um, you know your shortness of breath. You've mentioned you're wheezy, and you're coughing. Are you bringing up any phlegm at all?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, no I don't, um, I'm not covering up much <UNIN/>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, no sputum, OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Right <UNIN/>. And um, how are you using your, um, your <UNIN/>? So are you using it every day?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, I think I'm using that every day and the Salbutamol just like as and when

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: So, how are you using the <UNIN/>? Is it twice a day?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, yes <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNSURE>twice</UNSURE>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And have you ever been admitted in hospital because your <UNIN/> was so bad?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, no, I haven't.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNSURE>Righty-ho</UNSURE>. When was the last time you had an asthma attack?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, about three to four years ago.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Three to four years ago. And what, what did the GP do at that time?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, just, um, encourage me to carry on using my inhalers as a preventative.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. So you didn't have any <UNIN/> oral steroids or antibiotics?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Not that I can remember.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Um, OK. Right, <UNIN/> have you ever had oral steroids in the past?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, no.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: When was the last time you had an asthma review with our nurse?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, about two years ago.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Two years ago.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. But, your asthma was pretty under control till, till now, isn't it?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, yes, just in the last <UNSURE>two to three days</UNSURE> <UNIN/>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yes. So do you do a peak flow meter <UNSURE>at home</UNSURE>? Peak flow reading? Where you blow into, you know

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Do you do that? No?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, just every now and then. I haven't done overlap since I've has symptoms.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. So, what was <UNIN/> what's your peak flow reading when you're good?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Like normally <UNIN/> peak flow reading.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, I think <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Let's see it's about, um, three eighty, yeah? Yeah? <UNSURE> three </UNSURE> <UNIN/>. OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Right. So that's your normal, yeah? Righty-ho, OK. So what we need

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Mm-hmm.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Do you have any allergies at all?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Erm, I have a fever.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Sorry, could you repeat that please?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Sorry, I have hay fever.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNIN/> OK. <UNIN/> Now any <UNIN/> allergies to medication?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Ohh no <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. So you're not allergic to anything? OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: So no allergies. OK, excellent. Righty-ho.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: So what we need to do <UNSURE>that</UNSURE> obviously we <UNIN/> you haven't had an asthma check for sometime and it looks like you can be having a small, small exacerbation.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: So what, I would like you to be seen by one of our GP's in the next few days.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Mm-hmm.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: In the interim, what I'd like you to do is you can use your blue inhaler as and when.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. <UNSURE>You can</UNSURE> use it maximum about every two to four, four hours, but if you're using it that often that means pretty much that, you know, your asthma is really bad. You can use it, but that's not ideal.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Mm-hmm.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: But <UNIN/> uh, the brown <UNIN/> your Clenil. The brown inhaler.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: You can up the dose. If you're using just three puffs twice a day, you can increase it to four puffs twice a day.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah. And while, this is to do while you're waiting to see us.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Mm-hmm.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Now, <UNSURE>I've</UNSURE> mentioned, you know, you're doing <UNIN/> you know, increase the, uh, Clenil to four puffs twice a day and you're using the asthma, you know, the blue inhalers every two to four hours.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And your breathing is getting really worse, then you would need to take yourself to <UNSURE>A and E</UNSURE>. You shouldn't wait for our appointment.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. So, when <UNSURE>you'd opt to sneeze</UNSURE> you, what we're going to do is we're gonna examine your chest, yeah.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNSURE>Yeah</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Make you do the <UNSURE>peak flow reading</UNSURE>. So depending on what we find, you might need some antibiotics and some steroids.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: But anyway, while you're at home, we're going to <UNIN/> by increasing your Clenil, we are increasing your steroid intake anyway.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: So, yeah. So, any questions you wanted to ask me? <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No, that's <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> <UNSURE>thanks</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah. So, book an <UNIN/> call support, book an appointment to see and I will recommend that <UNSURE>meet her</UNSURE> face to face.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: In the interim, increase your brown inhaler to four puffs twice a day, and your salbutamol inhalers up to every two hourly. But, if you breathing's getting worse and you've not seen us, do take your <UNSURE>puffs to A and E</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: All right?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Great, OK. Thank you so much for your time. Thank you. <UNIN/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNIN/> You're welcome. You take care then, bye, bye now, bye. Bye.
